The Buttonwillow Warehouse Company, Inc. - Buttonwillow Service Yard is located at 401 Front st., Buttonwillow, CA 93206. The primary activity at the Facility is the storage, and sale of fertilizers, to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application for crop production nutrients.

The Buttonwillow Warehouse Company, Inc. has developed a risk management program to address the EPA RMP Program requirements (Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) A?Risk Management Plan (RMP)A? 40 CFR A?68).  The facility is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  The facilityA?s staff is trained and utilizes equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely storing and distributing anhydrous ammonia. This is a EPA RMP Program 3 facility.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Buttonwillow Warehouse Company, Inc. has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the ammonia storage and distribution system.  It is the Buttonwillow Warehouse Company's policy  to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated toxic substances.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The Buttonwillow Service Yard facility receives, stores, and distributes anhydrous ammonia.  There is a lone 31,160 gallon storage tank at the facility with a maximum capacity of 24,928 gallons.  The storage level on the storage tank is administratively controlled not to exceed 80% of each tankA?s maximum capacity. The Buttonwillow Service Yard Facility currently uses 128,379 lbs of toxic materials, which consists of the contents of the lone 31,360 gallon storage tank.  

The system is composed of the following key equipment:
-31,360

gallon storage tank

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFF SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary:

Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one toxic worst-case analysis has been defined for the storage of anhydrous ammonia.  The worst-case scenario is presented in the Hazard Assessment section of the RMP folder. 

Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary:

Scenario Description: A realistic toxic alternative release scenario was modeled utilizing a pressure relief valve (PRV) failure. The alternative release scenario is presented in the Hazard Assessment section of the RMP folder. 

Off-site Receptors
RMP requirements state that sensitive populations such as schools, hospitals, day-care centers, long-term health care facilities, prisons, residential areas, public use parks/recreational areas, and major commercial facilities, located within the A?at riskA? area must be identified.  These sensitive populations include individuals who could not remove themselves from the exposure area without assistance.  The sensitive populations also include industrial installations which may have a hazardous process that can not be immediately left unattended. 

Risk Considerations
Although the storage and distribution of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and the worst-case release scenarios will likely reach a community; the Buttonwillow Warehouse Company, Inc., has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other ch

aracteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a toxic material release:
-The system has relief valves
-The system has manual shutoffs
-The system has rupture disks
-The system has Excess flow devices
-The system has ammonia detectors

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
As part of the implementation of this RMP Program, key Prevention Program elements were implemented by Buttonwillow Warehouse Company to manage process safety issues associated with the storage and distribution of anhydrous ammonia.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.
The toxic material Prevention Program 3 elements include:
- Process Safety Information
- Process Hazard Analysis
- Operating Procedures
- Training
- Mechanical Integrity
- Management of Change
- Pre-Startup Safety Review
- Compliance Audits
- Incident Investigation
- Employee Participation
- Hot Work Permit
- Contractors
- Emergency Planning and Response

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no RMP-applicable releases of toxic materials at the facility in at least the past five (5) years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Buttonwillow Warehouse Company, Inc. maintains an emergency response plan in compliance with local emergency response agencies. Procedures for evacuation and notification are located in the Emergency Action Plan.
